issues.title: The validity VS. max-allowed-end parameter in generic-schedule-params grouping
issues.author: QiufangMa
issues.body:
How to understand the difference between the validity and max-allowed-end? Both seem refer to a maximum time upper limit.
https://github.com/netmod-wg/schedule-yang/blob/main/yang/ietf-schedule.yang#L240
https://github.com/netmod-wg/schedule-yang/blob/main/yang/ietf-schedule.yang#L268

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
As indicated in the text, what takes precedence is the validity. 

Validity controls when a schedule can be executed independent of when that a schedule ends. The other one is more specific as it reasons about  when a scheduled event will ends. Having both is still OK as soon as we are clear about the one that takes precedence (which we do). This provides more flexibility to the "consumers" of the common model. 

Thanks

issues.title: Erik Kline Comment at IETF#119/TVR
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/minutes-119-tvr-202403200300/, especially the following:


> Erik Kline: sldie 5, timezones makes everything worse. datetime start is
> bad name. call it "utc start time". interval vs duration?
> 
> possibly going to be removed, working with schedule authors for specific
> grouping for tvr
> 
> Erik Kline: If you want to recurr make the control system do it if want
> to make truly simple. so remove that from model.
>

comments.author: QiufangMa
comments.body: Can you give me the section number in 8413 where the examples we can imitate?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
The example can be drawn with a ref to this part: this is a simple start/end time schedule.

[4.1](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8413#section-4.1).  Service Request

   As shown in Figure 2, some component in the network requests a
   service.  This may be an application, an NMS, an LSR, or any
   component that qualifies as a Path Computation Client (PCC).  We show
   this on the figure as the "Service Requester", and it sends a request
   to the PCE for an LSP to be set up at some time (either now or in the
   future).  The request, indicated on Figure 2 by the arrow (a),
   includes all of the parameters of the LSP that the requester wishes
   to supply, such as priority, bandwidth, start time, and end time.
   Note that the requester in this case may be the LSR shown in the
   figure or may be a distinct system.

comments.author: QiufangMa
comments.body: This seems about how the scheduling could be managed/implemented, but I am not sure if this falls within our scope.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: What we need to show is that how the simple period structure is sufficient for this case.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: fixed in #35

issues.title: Updated text for Discussion Venues
issues.author: danielkinguk
issues.body:
Current text in "Discussion Venues" section was left over from policy-based-network-acl.

Suggested text: 

This note is to be removed before publishing as an RFC.

Discussion of this document takes place on the Network Modeling (NETMOD) Working Group mailing list (netmod@ietf.org), which is archived at https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/netmod/.

Source for this draft and an issue tracker can be found at https://github.com/netmod-wg/schedule-yang.

issues.title: too many recurrence-related groupings?
issues.author: QiufangMa
issues.body:
I feel that there are too many recurrence related groupings (6 of them):
recurrence
recurrence-utc
recurrence-with-time-zone
recurrence-utc-with-date-times
recurrence-time-zone-with-date-times
icalendar-recurrence

maybe remove recurrence-XX-with-date-times ones as I assume they are less useful than others?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: I don't see that as an issue. That's even a feature as it allows for better modularity and adaptability to future uses.

issues.title: schedule-status vs. schedule-status-with-name
issues.author: QiufangMa
issues.body:
compared to “schedule-status”, "schedule-status-with-name" grouping has an additional para named "schedule-id", which is needed in cases with multiple scheduling definition. But it is probably also needed for grouping generic-schedule-params. 
I am thinking a more concise representation, maybe we can define a feature called, e..g, multiple-schedule. and we can have the following:
     grouping schedule-status-with-name:
       **+-- schedule-id?         string {multiple-schedule}?**       
         ...
      grouping generic-schedule-params:
       **+-- schedule-id?         string {multiple-schedule}?**       
         ...
and also remove the schedule-status grouping. 
Would this be better?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
That's possible, but assumes a refine statement to strip the id for uses which does not require such parameter.

I still prefer simple reuses rather than conditional (although perfect) compact groupings.

pulls.title: default values may be problematic in some usages
pulls.author: boucadair

comments.author: QiufangMa
comments.body:
These are the nodes that should be mandatory to have values, otherwise, the recurrence behavior is unclear.
e.g., when it is a "daily" recurrence, it is unknown whether it is everyday or every N days.
we could have "everyday" by default (default interval value is 1), but could also be "every three days" by explicitly setting the "interval" value as 3.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> These are the nodes that should be mandatory to have values, otherwise, the recurrence behavior is unclear.

I think we just need to indicate the default value as part of the description not as a yang statement. The narrative text can explain the implication of not supplying interval, for example.

The concern I'm seeing with having a default is that if we define some profile that uses the grouping, and the same grouping is used by a router (for example) in addition to the profile, the default value will override what is in the profile.

comments.author: QiufangMa
comments.body:
> The concern I'm seeing with having a default is that if we define some profile that uses the grouping, and the same grouping is used by a router (for example) in addition to the profile, the default value will override what is in the profile.

Is the profile intended to use another value for default? I am assuming the default value defined here is applicable for all cases, but i also agree no one could stop a default value being refined when "uses" the groupings...

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Is the profile intended to use another value for default?

Yes. 

However, the key comment is that we should be careful to not impact how the grps will be reused.

comments.author: QiufangMa
comments.body:
> However, the key comment is that we should be careful to not impact how the grps will be reused.

Sure. While I see no difference to describe the default value in the desc compared with using the "default" statement, if two consumers have different understandings of the default behavior (e.g., the profile refine the description with another default  value). 
Maybe define as "mandatory true"?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: I would soften the constraints and have in the description as much guidance. So, no mandatory/default is still my preference here.

comments.author: QiufangMa
comments.body:
> I would soften the constraints and have in the description as much guidance.

okay, let's proceed with this way for now, and see if there is any objection from others in the future.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> > I would soften the constraints and have in the description as much guidance.
> 
> okay, let's proceed with this way for now, and see if there is any objection from others in the future.

Thanks.

pulls.title: update description and change discard-action type as identityref
pulls.author: QiufangMa
pulls.body:
In the abstract, I was not sure how to parse "..scheduling information such as event, policy, services, or resources..", are these examples well known and established as scheduling information?
Med: Fixed/

The introduction made sense as a motivation for the document initially, but it should be rephrased esp that the referenced modules are expected to be updated to use this common module going forward. You may create an appendix with this historical context if needed.
Med: Fixed

Section 3.1, the description is a bit sparse; also there are no examples that use this grouping. Please expand.
Qiufang: Fixed in https://github.com/netmod-wg/schedule-yang/pull/9.

The description inside the YANG module is old and incorrect, it says 2 groupings and focused only on iCalendar.
Qiufang: Fixed.

s/RFC XXXX: A YANG Data Model for Scheduling/RFC XXXX: A Common YANG Data Model for Scheduling/
Med: Fixed

for discard-action, is there a possibility for creating new actions in future or these two are the only ones? I am asking to make sure that the choice of modeling this as enum is correct or not.
Qiufang: Fixed

In these lists "leaf-list date-times" and "leaf-list dates", is there any ordering constraint that should be added explicitly in text?
Qiufang: No leaf-list date-times and dates definition in the current module anymore; I don't think ordering affects the recurrence rules

Section 3.4 needs more descriptive text for period and timeticks. The yang module has a long must statement for verification that should be explained here in text.

Section 3.5 needs more descriptive text for by* leaves -> "An array of the "bysecond" (or "byminut", "byhour") specifies a list of seconds within a minute (or minutes within an hour, hours of the day)." The examples in the appendix gave some hints but the description should be clearer.

s/byminut/byminute/
Med: Fixed

Appendix A.1, the text says end date is Dec 31, 2027 but the JSON says 1st Dec - "2027-12-01T18:00:00Z"
Med: Fixed

Appendix A.2, the text says Dec 1, 2025 but the example says 1st Nov - "2025-11-01T15:00:00"
Med: Fixed

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body: For the end thing, we need to reason as a function of the duration.

comments.body:
```suggestion
          "Adds a parameter indicating how long the occurrence 
```

```suggestion
   the last occurrence. A requested schedule will be rejected if the duration of the last
```

I think you mean the schedule needs to finish before the max-allowed-end. Would this be better:
A requested schedule will be rejected if the end time of last occurrence is later than the configured "max-allowed-end" value.
deal! Thanks/

pulls.title: clarifications + cite an OLD draft + clean up
pulls.author: boucadair

comments.body:
```suggestion
The interval specifies when a schedule will occur, combined with the frequency parameter; while the duration indicates how long
```
What is the difference between one-shot and period? One-shot starts at a specific instant time without indicating the duration/end?
This is no periodicity/recurrence at all in a one-shot schedule. We need to this type to ease mapping with the MIB in [RFC 3231](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3231)

Okay, I don't know the existence of RFC 3231 before, thanks for the info. While I found RFC 3231 defines three types of schedules that cannot be directly mapped to ours according to the naming rules:
1. Periodic schedules, defined by specifying **the number of seconds** between two initiations, I understand this as a recurrence rule like every 4 seconds to trigger the action. This is very different from the period-of-time grouping we have defined, which describes a specific duration of time; but instead kind of a recurrence definition.
2. Calendar Schedules, trigger scheduled actions at specified days of the week and days of the month. similar to our recurrence related definition, no issues.
3. One-shot Schedules, automatically disable itself once an action has been invoked, this is actually the one I feel like similar to period-of-time.

IMO it is confusing to have both this one-shot identity and the period (different from periodic) as schedule-types, though the only difference might be, by specifying one-shot, the users are not allowed to provide the duration/end time of the trigger. but it is not mandatory to specify duration/period-end in the period-of-time grouping.

The main difference I see between a one-shot and period of time is that the end time is not required to be configured but determined by the action. The end will be a read-only while this can be configured for a period.

I agree with that, could the difference be stated in the description? e.g., 
description for one-shot identity:
      "Indicates a one-shot schedule. That's a schedule that
       will trigger an action without the duration/end time being
       specified and then the schedule will disable itself.";

description for period identity:
      "Indicates a period-based schedule consisting either a 
        start and end or a start and positive duration of time.";

Just want to make sure there is no overlap between two identities.
Fair enough. Done.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Adding the description node into generic-schedule-params might be good (as this is the common and generic parameter), but that way i don't feel it necessary to also be defined in the period and recurrence. Thoughts?

From an ops standpoint, description fields are very useful as this is a placeholder for recording contexts, etc. Parent "description" field might not be sufficient in all contexts.

comments.author: QiufangMa
comments.body:
> > Adding the description node into generic-schedule-params might be good (as this is the common and generic parameter), but that way i don't feel it necessary to also be defined in the period and recurrence. Thoughts?
> 
> From an ops standpoint, description fields are very useful as this is a placeholder for recording contexts, etc. Parent "description" field might not be sufficient in all contexts.

Are you referring to description for each single recurrence/period entry? It seems okay to me then. I worry slightly that we are making the schedule yang definition huger and huger;-）

reviews.author: QiufangMa
reviews.body: Adding the description node into generic-schedule-params might be good (as this is the common and generic parameter), but that way i don't feel it necessary to also be defined in the period and recurrence. Thoughts?

pulls.title: cover contexts where the grouping is used in a schedule request
pulls.author: boucadair
pulls.body: The type/state can be tweaked in a request.

pulls.title: report local time
pulls.author: boucadair
pulls.body:
schedLocalTime OBJECT-TYPE
       SYNTAX      DateAndTime (SIZE (11))
       MAX-ACCESS  read-only
       STATUS      current
       DESCRIPTION
           "The local time used by the scheduler.  Schedules which
            refer to calendar time will use the local time indicated
            by this object.  An implementation MUST return all 11 bytes
            of the DateAndTime textual-convention so that a manager
            may retrieve the offset from GMT time."
       ::= { schedObjects 1 }

comments.body:
```suggestion
         hosts the schedule. This parameter is only reported if schedule is expressed in local time format.";
```
Note that 3231 requires calendar schedules are always expressed in local time. I think if the schedule is using UTC time, no need to know the local time info.
I guess I don't really understand what time is reported by this parameter? The time when this value is retrieved? or the time when the schedule is managed?

You are right for calendar schedules, but other types do not have such restriction. 

This will report the actual local-time as seen by the entity. 

No need to restrict the attribute to non UTC but leave that the manager to infer whatever useful from the parameter.
Sure, I think I can live with that.

```suggestion
|schedLastFailed|   last-failed-occurrence|
```

```suggestion
|schedAdminStatus|   state|
```

```suggestion
|schedOperStatus|  state|
```
We don't restrict state to be rw or ro.

pulls.title: add schedTriggers
pulls.author: QiufangMa
pulls.body:
schedValue is "The value which is written to the MIB object pointed to by
            schedVariable when the scheduler invokes an action."
schedVariable is "An object identifier pointing to a local MIB variable
            which resolves to an ASN.1 primitive type of INTEGER."
both seem parameters specific to SNMP, and thus may be omitted from the mapping?

Meanwhile, schedTriggers : "This variable counts the number of attempts (either
            successful or failed) to invoke the scheduled action." this seems to be related to leaf "counter" inside schedule-status grouping...

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
I agree that schedValue is not applicable in our context. This is why we had it "not supported" in the table. Instead of deleting the entry, we may s/not supported/not applicable.

For schedTriggers, we do have both successful and failures in separate counters. Don't see the value to support this as a separate parameter. We may indicate in the table that it is covered by failure-counter + counter.

comments.author: QiufangMa
comments.body:
> I agree that schedValue is not applicable in our context. This is why we had it "not supported" in the table. Instead of deleting the entry, we may s/not supported/not applicable.

If this is the case, then i guess schedVariable should also be added in the table?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> schedVariable

Agree, assuming we say not applicable.

```suggestion
|schedValue|  Not Applicable|
|schedTriggers|  counter/failure-counter   |
```
